questions.text: Which of the following is true about breastmilk jaundice?

options.label: B
options.text: Most of the children require phototherapy

options.label: C
options.text: Exclusive breastfeeding with total bilirubin >10mg/dl after 3-4 weeks of birth

questions.correct_answer: C. Exclusive breastfeeding with total bilirubin >10mg/dl after 3-4 weeks of birth
questions.explanation:
Kramer Zone

Region

Estimated TSB Level (mg/dL)

Zone 1

Face and neck

5–7 mg/dL

Zone 2

Chest and upper abdomen

7–9 mg/dL

Zone 3

Lower abdomen and thighs

9–11 mg/dL

Zone 4

Arms, forearms, and legs

11–13 mg/dL

Zone 5

questions.text: Exclusive breastfeeding should be continued for a minimum of how many months?
Specific sign of kwashiorkor is:
questions.explanation:
Features of Kwashiorkar and Marasmus

Kwashiorkor

Marasmus

Pitting Edema: Specific sign of Kwashiorkar Characterized by swelling, often starting in the legs and feet, leaving a persistent indentation when pressed.

Severe Wasting: The child appears extremely thin, with prominent bones and little body fat.

Sugar Baby Appearance: The child may look deceptively healthy due to oedema, despite being malnourished.

Monkey Facies: A sunken appearance of the cheeks due to loss of fat, giving an aged look.

Muscle Wasting: Despite the swollen appearance, muscle loss is present, leading to weakness and hypotonia.

Baggy Pants Appearance: Loose, sagging skin around the buttocks caused by significant muscle and fat loss.

Mental and Neurological Symptoms: The child is apathetic, irritable, and may have feeding difficulties.

Alertness: Children with marasmus remain mentally alert.

Hair Changes: Hair may lose colour, become thin, and show alternating bands of colour ("flag sign").

Absence of Edema: Unlike kwashiorkor, marasmus does not involve swelling or oedema.

Skin Changes: Includes hyperpigmentation, peeling skin ("flaky paint" appearance), and colour changes, particularly in the buttocks, perineum, and thighs.

Hypoglycemia Risk: The liver's reduced capacity to produce glucose increases the risk of low blood sugar.
Gastrointestinal Issues: Anorexia, vomiting, and abdominal distension. Anaemia is present due to nutritional deficiencies. Hypothermia Risk: The child may struggle to maintain body temperature due to energy depletion.

questions.text: At what age is it recommended to introduce solid foods to an infant while continuing breastfeeding?

questions.explanation:

Age 1 to 3 years

Age 4 to 18 years

Carbohydrates

45- 65 %

45- 65 %

Fats

30- 40 %

25- 35 %

Protein

5- 20 %

10- 30 %

questions.text: A labourer's second child is brought to the outpatient department (OPD) with a swollen belly and dull face appearance. He has been fed rice water in his diet mostly. Further investigations revealed low levels of serum protein and albumin. What could be the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Kwashiorkor

Marasmus (Option B)

Pitting Edema: Characterized by swelling, often starting in the legs and feet, leaving a persistent indentation when pressed.

Severe Wasting: The child appears extremely thin, with prominent bones and little body fat.

Sugar Baby Appearance: The child may look deceptively healthy due to oedema, despite being malnourished.

Monkey Facies: A sunken appearance of the cheeks due to loss of fat, giving an aged look.

Muscle Wasting: Despite the swollen appearance, muscle loss is present, leading to weakness and hypotonia.

Baggy Pants Appearance: Loose, sagging skin around the buttocks caused by significant muscle and fat loss.

Mental and Neurological Symptoms: The child is apathetic, irritable, and may have feeding difficulties.

Alertness: Children with marasmus remain mentally alert.

Hair Changes: Hair may lose colour, become thin, and show alternating bands of colour ("flag sign").

Absence of Edema: Unlike kwashiorkor, marasmus does not involve swelling or oedema.

Skin Changes: Includes hyperpigmentation, peeling skin ("flaky paint" appearance), and colour changes, particularly in the buttocks, perineum, and thighs.

Hypoglycemia Risk: The liver's reduced capacity to produce glucose increases the risk of low blood sugar.

Gastrointestinal Issues: Anorexia, vomiting, and abdominal distension. Anaemia is present due to nutritional deficiencies.

Hypothermia Risk: The child may struggle to maintain body temperature due to energy depletion.

(Protein Calorie Malnutrition)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a criterion for severe acute malnutrition?

options.label: A
options.text: Weight for height less than -3 SD

options.label: D
options.text: Weight for age less than -3 SD

questions.correct_answer: D. Weight for age less than -3 SD

questions.text: During the anthropometric evaluation of the child, the height for the age is < -2 SD according to WHO growth charts. This is most likely due to:
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Chronic malnutrition:

Moderately underweight

Weight for age is between -2 and -3 SD.

Severely underweight

Weight for age is < -3 SD.

Moderately wasted

Weight for length/height is between -2 and -3 SD.

Severely wasted

Weight for length/height is < -3 SD.

Moderate Acute Malnutrition
  • Weight-for-length/height or BMI for age is between -2 and -3 SD.
  • Mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) is between 11.5 cm and 12.5 cm.

Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) :

 
  • Weight-for-length/height or BMI-for-age is less than -3SDS.
  • MUAC is less than 11.5 cm.
  • The presence of bilateral pitting oedema.

Moderately Stunted (Moderate Chronic Malnutrition)

Length/height for age is between -2 and -3 SD.

Severely Stunted (Severe Chronic Malnutrition)

Length/height for age is < -3 SD.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about colostrum?

options.label: A
options.text: It is the breastmilk that is seen in the initial 3-4 days

options.label: C
options.text: It contains a large number of antibodies

options.label: D
options.text: It contains a high amount of lactose and low amounts of protein

questions.correct_answer: D. It contains a high amount of lactose and low amounts of protein
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer D - It contains a high amount of lactose and low amounts of protein

Milk Type

Time of Production

Appearance

Quantity

Key Components

Colostrum

Initial 3-4 days after delivery (Option A)

Yellow and thick

(Option B)

Small
  • It is high in antibodies (Option C), immune-competent cells, and vitamins A, D, E, and K.
  • Rich in immunoglobulins and proteins.
  • Low in lactose

Transitional Milk

From 3-4 days until two weeks

Thinner than colostrum

Moderate
  • Decreased immunoglobulins and proteins.
  • Increased fat and sugar.

Mature Milk

Follows transitional milk

Thinner and watery

Variable
  • Consistent in nutrient composition
  • Balanced in nutrients essential for growth
  • Higher lactose content.

Kwashiorkor

Marasmus (Option B)

Pitting Edema: Characterized by swelling, often starting in the legs and feet, leaving a persistent indentation when pressed.

Severe Wasting: The child appears extremely thin, with prominent bones and little body fat.

Sugar Baby Appearance: The child may look deceptively healthy due to oedema, despite being malnourished.

Baggy Pants Appearance: Loose, sagging skin around the buttocks caused by significant muscle and fat loss.

Mental and Neurological Symptoms: The child is apathetic, irritable, and may have feeding difficulties.

Alertness: Children with marasmus remain mentally alert.

Hair Changes: Hair may lose colour, become thin, and show alternating bands of colour ("flag sign").

Absence of Edema: Unlike kwashiorkor, marasmus does not involve swelling or oedema.

Skin Changes: Includes hyperpigmentation, peeling skin ("flaky paint" appearance), and colour changes, particularly in the buttocks, perineum, and thighs.

questions.text: Which of the following is an absolute contraindication for breastfeeding?

options.label: D
options.text: Infants born to an HbsAg-positive mother

questions.correct_answer: B. Classic galactosemia in the infant
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Classic galactosemia in the infant

Breastfeeding Contraindications

Maternal Contraindications

Infectious Diseases:

 

Active Tuberculosis

Mothers with active tuberculosis should delay breastfeeding until they have completed at least two weeks of appropriate treatment to reduce the risk of transmission.

Active Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) Lesions on the Breast:

Breastfeeding is contraindicated if a mother has active herpetic lesions on her breast to prevent transmission to the infant.

Varicella-Zoster Infection

If the mother has active chickenpox lesions, breastfeeding should be avoided to prevent direct contact between the lesions and the infant. The infant should also receive appropriate immunoglobulin.

Medications and Treatments:

Chemotherapy, Radiopharmaceuticals and Certain Medications
  • Breastfeeding is usually contraindicated during maternal treatment with chemotherapy or radiopharmaceuticals due to the potential harm to the infant.
  • Specific medications, such as some anticoagulants, anti-tuberculosis drugs, and anticonvulsants, may require mothers to avoid breastfeeding.

Substance Use: Alcohol and Smoking

(Option A)

  • While not a strict contraindication, alcohol consumption should be limited to less than 0.5g/kg/day.
  • Cigarette smoking is strongly discouraged.

Maternal Health Conditions:

  • Severe Illness or Surgery
  • Breast Conditions
  • Maternal issues like mastitis or breast engorgement may complicate breastfeeding and require temporary cessation but are not absolute contraindications.

Fetal Contraindications

Metabolic Disorders: Galactosemia

Infants with galactosemia, a condition where they cannot process galactose, should not be breastfed. Instead, they require specialized formulas.

Anatomical Challenges: Oral or Facial Anomalies

Conditions like cleft palate that affect the infant's ability to suckle may necessitate alternative feeding methods.

Prematurity or Low Birth Weight: Support Needs

Premature or low-birth-weight infants may initially require supplemental feeding methods until they can effectively breastfeed.

questions.text: Which can be used as an alternative to mother’s milk in a low birth weight (LBW) baby?

Which of the following statements is true regarding the tape shown in the image? It is called Shelter's tape. It is used to assess severe acute malnutrition. Reading of 13.5 to 14.5 cm is considered undernourished. It is useful mainly for frontline field workers.
questions.explanation:
Mid Upper Arm Circumference (MUAC)

Definition
  • MUAC is a vital measurement used primarily to assess the nutritional status of children aged 6 months to 5 years.
  • Quick and effective screening tool.
  • In infants under 6 months old, the Mid-Upper Arm Circumference (MUAC) is not utilized as a measurement criterion. (G88)

Procedure
  • Ensure the child is standing straight with their left arm free of clothing. The arm should be bent at a right angle.
  • Measure the distance between the tip of the shoulder (acromion) and the tip of the elbow (olecranon). Mark the midpoint on the upper arm.
  • The child's arm should hang relaxed by their side, with the palm facing the thigh.
  • Use a MUAC tape to wrap around the marked midpoint of the arm. The tape should be snug but not tight enough to pinch the skin.
  • Record the measurement at the zero mark of the tape.

Shakir’s Tape

Shakir's tape (1) is a specific type of MUAC measuring tape designed for use in assessing malnutrition. (2)

Used by frontline field workers for nutritional screening of malnourished children. (4)

It is typically three colour-coded to facilitate easy interpretation of nutritional status. The tape is marked with different zones that correspond to various levels of malnutrition:

  • Red Zone: Indicates severe malnutrition (MUAC < 11.5 cm).
  • Yellow Zone: Indicates moderate malnutrition (MUAC between 11.5 cm and 12.5 cm).
  • Green Zone: Indicates healthy nutritional status (MUAC > 12.5 cm) (3)

 

SHAKIR’S TAPE

questions.correct_answer: A. Kwashiorkor due to protein malnutrition

Kwashiorkor

Marasmus

Pitting Edema: Characterized by swelling, often starting in the legs and feet, leaving a persistent indentation when pressed.

Severe Wasting: The child appears extremely thin, with prominent bones and little body fat.

Sugar Baby Appearance: The child may look deceptively healthy due to oedema, despite being malnourished.

Mental and Neurological Symptoms: The child is apathetic, irritable, and may have feeding difficulties.

Alertness: Children with marasmus remain mentally alert.

Hair Changes: Hair may lose colour, become thin, and show alternating bands of colour ("flag sign").

Absence of Edema: Unlike kwashiorkor, marasmus does not involve swelling or oedema.

Skin Changes: Includes hyperpigmentation, peeling skin ("flaky paint" appearance), and colour changes, particularly in the buttocks, perineum, and thighs.

Hypoglycemia Risk: The liver's reduced capacity to produce glucose increases the risk of low blood sugar.

Gastrointestinal Issues: Anorexia, vomiting, and abdominal distension. Anaemia is present due to nutritional deficiencies.

Hypothermia Risk: The child may struggle to maintain body temperature due to energy depletion.

questions.text: What is the fluid of choice for shock in a child with severe acute malnutrition?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer D - Ringer's lactate with 5% dextrose

Management of Severe Acute Malnutrition

Step

Diagnosis

Initial Management

Monitoring

1. Treat/Prevent Hypoglycemia

Blood glucose <54 mg/dL (3 mmol/L)

Asymptomatic:

  • 50 mL of 10% glucose/sucrose orally/NG
  • Follow with first feed
  • F-75 starter diet every 2 hours

Symptomatic:

  • 10% dextrose IV 5 mL/kg
  • Follow with 50 mL 10% glucose via NG tube
  • Start antibiotics immediately
  • Blood glucose every 30 minutes until stable
  • Level of consciousness
  • Vital signs every 2 hours
  • Feed intake volume
  • Signs of deterioration

2. Treat/Prevent Hypothermia

Temperature <35.5°C (rectal) or <35°C (axillary)

Immediate interventions:

  • Warm clothing with head cover
  • Skin-to-skin contact with mother
  • Warm room (25-30°C)
  • Warm feeds
  • Overhead warmer/heat convector

Avoid:

  • Rapid rewarming
  • Direct heat sources
  • Prolonged exposure
  • Temperature every 30 minutes until >36.5°C
  • Then every 2 hours until >37.5°C
  • Watch for overheating
  • Monitor blood glucose
  • Check for infection signs

3. Treat/Prevent Dehydration

Clinical signs:

  • Thirst
  • Sunken eyes
  • Reduced skin turgor
  • Weak pulses
  • Cold extremities

ReSoMal administration:

  • 5-10 mL/kg/hour for first 12 hours
  • Maximum 12 hours for rehydration
  • Replace ongoing losses

If shock present:

  • Ringer's lactate with 5% dextrose
  • 15 mL/kg over first hour
  • Reassess and repeat if needed

Every 30 minutes for first 2 hours:

  • Pulse rate
  • Respiratory rate
  • Urine output
  • Stool frequency
  • Signs of overhydration
  • Mental status

4. Correct Electrolyte Imbalance

Common abnormalities:

  • Hypokalemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Excess total body sodium
  • Metabolic acidosis

Potassium supplementation:

  • 3-4 mEq/kg/day
  • Continue for 2 weeks

Magnesium:

  • Day 1: 0.3 mL/kg IM (max 2 mL)
  • Then 0.8-1.2 mEq/kg/day oral

Restrict sodium intake
  • Daily electrolytes
  • ECG if severe hypokalemia
  • Clinical signs of deficiency
  • Urine output
  • Mental status changes

5. Treat/Prevent Infection

Screen for:

  • Sepsis
  • Pneumonia
  • UTI
  • TB
  • HIV
  • Malaria in endemic areas

First-line antibiotics:

  • Ampicillin 50 mg/kg 6 hourly
  • Gentamicin 7.5 mg/kg daily

If no improvement in 48h:

  • Cefotaxime 100-150 mg/kg/day
  • or Ceftriaxone 50-75 mg/kg/day
  • Temperature
  • Respiratory rate
  • Heart rate
  • Clinical response
  • Culture results
  • Inflammatory markers

6. Micronutrient Supplementation

Common deficiencies:

  • Vitamin A
  • Zinc
  • Iron
  • Folic acid
  • Copper
  • Other vitamins/minerals

Vitamin A (Day 1):

  • 6-12 months: 100,000 IU
  • >12 months: 200,000 IU

Daily supplements:

  • Folic acid 1mg/day
  • Zinc 2mg/kg/day
  • Copper 0.2-0.3 mg/kg/day
  • Iron 3mg/kg/day (after stabilization)
  • Clinical signs of deficiency
  • Response to therapy
  • Weight gain
  • Appetite improvement
  • Complications

7. Initiate Feeding

Assessment:

  • Appetite
  • Ability to feed
  • Complications
  • Metabolic status

Initial feeding:

  • F-75 formula (75 kcal/100 mL)
  • Start 80 kcal/kg/day
  • Increase to 100 kcal/kg/day
  • 2-hourly feeds initially

Volume per feed:

11 mL/kg/feed initially
  • Feed tolerance
  • Volume consumed
  • Weight changes
  • Edema
  • Vomiting/diarrhea
  • Refeeding syndrome

8. Catch-up Growth

Indicators for transition:

  • Return of appetite
  • Reduced/resolved edema
  • Metabolic stability
  • Infection control

Transition to F-100:

  • Increase to 150-200 kcal/kg/day
  • Protein 4-6 g/kg/day
  • 6 feeds per day
  • Gradual volume increase

Target weight gain: >10 g/kg/day
  • Daily weight
  • Height weekly
  • MUAC weekly
  • Appetite
  • Clinical status
  • Feed intake

9. Sensory Stimulation

Assess:

  • Developmental status
  • Interaction level
  • Physical capabilities
  • Emotional state

Daily activities:

  • Structured play 15-30 min
  • Physical activity as tolerated
  • Emotional support
  • Mother-child bonding
  • Age-appropriate stimulation
  • Development progress
  • Activity level
  • Social interaction
  • Emotional response
  • Motor skills

10. Prepare for Follow-up

Discharge criteria:

  • No edema x 2 weeks
  • Weight-for-height > -2 SD
  • Good appetite
  • Clinically well
  • Completed immunizations

Discharge planning:

  • Family education
  • Follow-up schedule
  • Community health worker linkage
  • Emergency care plan
  • Nutrition counseling

Post-discharge:

  • Weekly follow-up initially
  • Monthly weight checks
  • Growth monitoring
  • Development assessment
  • Immunization status

WHO Classification of Malnutrition

Moderately underweight

Weight-for-age is between -2 and -3 SDS.

Severely underweight

Weight-for-age is < -3 SDS.

Moderately wasted

Weight-for-length/height is between -2 and -3 SDS.

Severely wasted

Weight-for-length/height is < -3 SDS.

Moderate Acute Malnutrition
  • Weight-for-length/height or BMI-for-age is between -2 and -3 SDS.
  • Mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) is between 11.5 cm and 12.5 cm.

Severe Acute Malnutrition:
  • Weight-for-length/height or BMI-for-age is less than -3SDS.
  • MUAC is less than 11.5 cm.
  • The presence of bilateral pitting oedema.

Moderately Stunted (Moderate Chronic Malnutrition)

Length/height-for-age is between -2 and -3 SDS.

Severely Stunted (Severe Chronic Malnutrition)

Length/height-for-age is < -3 SDS.

questions.text: Which of the following indicates the primary failure of recovery in an admitted patient with severe acute malnutrition? A. Failure to regain appetite by day 4 B. Failure to start to lose edema by day 4 C. Presence of edema by day 10 D. Weight gain of less than 5gm/kg/day from day 20
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Learning Objective:
  • ➤ SAM- Nutritional Rehabilitation Phase and Discharge Nutritional Rehabilitation Entry to Rehabilitation Phase: Indicated by reduced or minimal oedema and a return of appetite. Transition Process: Duration: Over 3 days to prevent refeeding syndrome. Method: Replace F75 with an equal volume of F100 for 2 days. Gradual Increase: Increase feed volume by 10 mL at each feeding until some feed remains uneaten (around 200 mL/kg/day). Post-Transition Feeding: Feeds: Provide unlimited amounts of high-energy, high-protein milk formula like F100 (100 kcal and 3 g protein per 100 mL), ready-to-use therapeutic food (RUTF), or modified family foods with similar energy and protein content. (Option C) Calories and Protein: Offer 150-220 kcal/kg/day and 4-6 g protein/kg/day. Supplements: Continue potassium, magnesium, and micronutrients. Add iron at 3 mg/kg/day. Breastfeeding: Encourage continued breastfeeding if applicable. RUTF Standard ready-to-use therapeutic food (RUTF) usually contains milk powder, sugar, peanut butter, vegetable oil, vitamins, and minerals. It has a long shelf life and low moisture content- preventing the growth of pathogens. When using RUTF: Begin with small, frequent meals of RUTF, aiming for 8 meals per day initially and then reducing to 5–6 meals per day. If the child cannot consume the full RUTF portion at each meal, supplement with F-75 to complete the meal until they can eat the full amount of RUTF. If the child is unable to consume at least half of the recommended RUTF amount within 12 hours, discontinue RUTF and provide F-75 instead. Reintroduce RUTF after 1–2 days and continue this approach until the child can consume sufficient RUTF. If the child is still breastfeeding, offer breast milk before each RUTF feeding. Discharge criteria All medical issues, including oedema, are resolved for 2 weeks They have completed parenteral antibiotic treatment and the infant is clinically stable and alert. The infant is either breastfeeding effectively or feeding well. The weight gain is satisfactory, such as being above the median of WHO growth velocity standards or gaining more than 5g/kg/day for at least 3 consecutive days. Before discharge, check and provide any missing vaccinations and routine interventions as needed. Ensure that mothers or caregivers are connected with appropriate community follow-up and support.

(Option C) Calories and Protein: Offer 150-220 kcal/kg/day and 4-6 g protein/kg/day. Supplements: Continue potassium, magnesium, and micronutrients. Add iron at 3 mg/kg/day. Before discharge, check and provide any missing vaccinations and routine interventions as needed. Ensure that mothers or caregivers are connected with appropriate community follow-up and support.

  • ➤ Discharge criteria

The infant is either breastfeeding effectively or feeding well. The weight gain is satisfactory, such as being above the median of WHO growth velocity standards or gaining more than 5g/kg/day for at least 3 consecutive days. Before discharge, check and provide any missing vaccinations and routine interventions as needed. Ensure that mothers or caregivers are connected with appropriate community follow-up and support.

The infant is either breastfeeding effectively or feeding well. The weight gain is satisfactory, such as being above the median of WHO growth velocity standards or gaining more than 5g/kg/day for at least 3 consecutive days. Before discharge, check and provide any missing vaccinations and routine interventions as needed. Ensure that mothers or caregivers are connected with appropriate community follow-up and support.
  • ➤ All medical issues, including oedema, are resolved for 2 weeks
  • ➤ They have completed parenteral antibiotic treatment and the infant is clinically stable and alert.
  • ➤ The infant is either breastfeeding effectively or feeding well.
  • ➤ The weight gain is satisfactory, such as being above the median of WHO growth velocity standards or gaining more than 5g/kg/day for at least 3 consecutive days.
  • ➤ Before discharge, check and provide any missing vaccinations and routine interventions as needed. Ensure that mothers or caregivers are connected with appropriate community follow-up and support.

SAM- Nutritional Rehabilitation Phase and Discharge

Nutritional Rehabilitation

Entry to Rehabilitation Phase:

  • Indicated by reduced or minimal oedema and a return of appetite.

Transition Process:

  • Duration: Over 3 days to prevent refeeding syndrome.
  • Method: Replace F75 with an equal volume of F100 for 2 days.
  • Gradual Increase: Increase feed volume by 10 mL at each feeding until some feed remains uneaten (around 200 mL/kg/day).

Post-Transition Feeding:

  • Feeds: Provide unlimited amounts of high-energy, high-protein milk formula like F100 (100 kcal and 3 g protein per 100 mL), ready-to-use therapeutic food (RUTF), or modified family foods with similar energy and protein content. (Option C)
  • Calories and Protein: Offer 150-220 kcal/kg/day and 4-6 g protein/kg/day.
  • Supplements: Continue potassium, magnesium, and micronutrients. Add iron at 3 mg/kg/day.
  • Breastfeeding: Encourage continued breastfeeding if applicable.

RUTF
  • Standard ready-to-use therapeutic food (RUTF) usually contains milk powder, sugar, peanut butter, vegetable oil, vitamins, and minerals.
  • It has a long shelf life and low moisture content- preventing the growth of pathogens.

When using RUTF:

  • Begin with small, frequent meals of RUTF, aiming for 8 meals per day initially and then reducing to 5–6 meals per day. If the child cannot consume the full RUTF portion at each meal, supplement with F-75 to complete the meal until they can eat the full amount of RUTF.
  • If the child is unable to consume at least half of the recommended RUTF amount within 12 hours, discontinue RUTF and provide F-75 instead. Reintroduce RUTF after 1–2 days and continue this approach until the child can consume sufficient RUTF.
  • If the child is still breastfeeding, offer breast milk before each RUTF feeding.

Discharge criteria
  • All medical issues, including oedema, are resolved for 2 weeks
  • They have completed parenteral antibiotic treatment and the infant is clinically stable and alert.
  • The infant is either breastfeeding effectively or feeding well.
  • The weight gain is satisfactory, such as being above the median of WHO growth velocity standards or gaining more than 5g/kg/day for at least 3 consecutive days.
  • Before discharge, check and provide any missing vaccinations and routine interventions as needed. Ensure that mothers or caregivers are connected with appropriate community follow-up and support.

questions.text: Chronic malnutrition is best measured by?
questions.explanation:
WHO Classification of Malnutrition

Moderately underweight

Weight-for-age is between -2 and -3 SDs.

Severely underweight

Weight-for-age is < -3 SDs.

Moderately wasted

Weight-for-length/height is between -2 and -3 SDs.

Severely wasted

Weight-for-length/height is < -3 SDs.

Moderate Acute Malnutrition
  • Weight-for-length/height or BMI-for-age is between -2 and -3 SDs.
  • Mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) is between 11.5 cm and 12.5 cm.

Severe Acute Malnutrition:
  • Weight-for-length/height or BMI-for-age is less than -3SDs.
  • MUAC is less than 11.5 cm.
  • The presence of bilateral pitting oedema.

Moderately Stunted (Moderate Chronic Malnutrition)

Length/height-for-age is between -2 and -3 SDs.

Severely Stunted (Severe Chronic Malnutrition)

Length/height-for-age is < -3 SDs.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child with mid-arm circumference of 105mm, upon providing therapeutic food, eagerly completed all of it. This patient is considered under?
questions.explanation:
Criteria

Details

Diagnostic Criteria for SAM

Assessment for Complications

Check for the following complications:

  • Severe edema (+++)
  • Low appetite (fails appetite test)
  • Medical complications
  • Presence of one or more danger signs (as per IMNCI guidelines)

Management Approach

Based on the presence or absence of complications:

  • If NO complications → Uncomplicated SAM → Supervised home management
  • If YES (complications present) → Complicated SAM → Inpatient management in a healthcare facility

questions.text: In a child presenting with diarrhoea, the following finding is noted. What is the likely micronutrient deficiency?

A child presents with generalized body aches, poor wound healing, and corkscrew hairs on her arms, and white lines of Frenkel on X-ray as shown below. This clinical presentation is most consistent with which of the following deficiencies?
questions.explanation: Correct  Option B

questions.text: A child with diarrhea was eager to drink, and the skin pinch went back slowly. Which of the following categories is the child classified into as per IMNCI?
questions.explanation:
Parameters

No Dehydration (Green) (Option C)

Some Dehydration (Yellow) (Option B)

Severe Dehydration (Pink) (Option A)

Sensorium

Well alert

Restless, irritable

Lethargic, floppy

Eyes

Normal

Sunken

Very sunken

Tears

Present

Absent

Absent

Mucosa

Moist

Dry

Very dry

Thirst

Drinks normally

Thirsty, drinks eagerly

Drinks poorly/unable

Skin pinch

Goes back quickly

Goes back slowly (<2 sec)

Goes back very slowly (>2 sec)

questions.text: Conjunctival xerosis is caused by which vitamin deficiency?
questions.explanation:
WHO Grading of eye signs of vitamin A deficiency (VAD) in children

Grade

Eye Sign

XN

Night blindness

X1A

Conjunctival xerosis

X1B

Bitot's spots

X2

Corneal xerosis

X3A

Corneal ulcer covering less than 1/3 of the cornea

X3B

Corneal ulcer covering at least 1/3 of the cornea

XS

Corneal scarring

Management of Vit A deficiency

Standard Oral Treatment
  • Children <6 months: 50,000 IU
  • Children 6-12 months: 100,000 IU
  • Children >1 year: 200,000 IU

Administration Schedule
  • Initial dose
  • Repeat same dose next day
  • Final dose 4 weeks later

Parenteral Administration(For severe malabsorption or persistent vomiting)
  • Children <6 months: 75% of oral dose
  • Children ≥6 months: 50% of oral dose

Ocular Emergencies
  • Corneal clouding: Immediate parenteral administration of 50,000-100,000 IU (15-30 mg retinol)
  • Keratomalacia: Antibiotic drops/ointment and eye padding

Vitamin A Prophylaxis in Children

Age

Dose

Administration Timing

9 months

100,000 IU

With measles vaccine

15-18 months

200,000 IU

With DPT booster

18 months - 5 years

200,000 IU

Every 6 months

Special Cases

 

 

Children with measles or severe malnutrition <1 year

100,000 IU

During illness

Children with measles or severe malnutrition >1 year

200,000 IU

During illness

questions.text: Feature of angular cheilitis, stomatitis, and glossitis is seen in which vitamin deficiency?
questions.explanation:
Vitamin B2 Deficiency

 

Riboflavin (B2) deficiency

Cause
  • Malnutrition
  • Malabsorption
  • Certain medications
  • Phototherapy

Clinical features:

Cheilosis, glossitis, keratitis, conjunctivitis, seborrheic dermatitis, anemia, photophobia.

Diagnosis:

Clinical response to supplementation, EGR (Erythrocyte Glutathione Reductase) activity test, low urinary riboflavin.

Treatment:

Oral riboflavin 3-10 mg/day, balanced diet including dairy products

questions.text: A child presents to the OPD with fatigue, bone pains, and swollen and bleeding gums. Physical examination reveals petechiae on her skin. Which of the following can be given to treat her condition?
questions.explanation:
Vitamin C Source:

Citrus fruits/juices, cauliflower and green leafy vegetables, melons, guava.

Vitamin C RDA (Infants)

0-6 months- 40 mg/day

7-12 months- 50 mg/day

Vitamin C Deficiency (Scurvy)

Causes:
  • Heat-treated milk or unfortified formula.
  • Diets lacking fruits and vegetables.

Symptoms:
  • Early: Irritability, loss of appetite, fever, pain, leg tenderness.
  • Later: Swelling, pseudoparalysis, subperiosteal hemorrhages, "scorbutic rosary" beads at the costochondral junction due to periosteal bleeds, gum changes, anemia, bleeding, poor healing.

Treatment:

  • Vitamin C 100-200 mg/day (oral or parenteral).
  • Improvement within a week; continue for 3 months.

Feature

Scorbutic Rosary

Rickety Rosary

Definition

Sharp angulation of ribs with or without beading

Bead-like enlargement of costochondral junction

Underlying cause

Vitamin C deficiency (scurvy)

Vitamin D deficiency (rickets)

Mechanism

Due to periosteal bleeds

Overgrowth of cartilage at costochondral junction

Palpation

Sharp, angular prominences

Rounded, knob-like prominences

questions.text: Which of the following is a reliable sign of some dehydration in severe acute malnutrition?

options.label: C
options.text: Skin pinch that goes back slowly

questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Increased Th

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in nutritional rickets?
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - Urine calcium: creatinine > 15mg/kg

questions.text: A child presented to the clinic with complaints of malnutrition and severe dehydration. What would be the choice of IV fluid for this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - RL in 5% D

questions.text: Pellagra like rash is seen in:
questions.explanation: Correct option C: Hartnu

questions.text: In an eye camp, doctors try to make people aware of the causes of blindness. Vitamin A is the leading cause of preventable childhood blindness. A parent brings her 18-month-old child to the doctor for a routine eye check-up. The doctor notices a thinned-out cornea, and from old records, it was seen that the child also has iron-deficiency anemia. If the weight of the child is 10kg, what should be the dose of vitamin A to be given in this case if the doctor marks it as keratomalacia?
questions.explanation:
Correct option C: 2,00,000 IU

  < 6 months 6 months - 1 year > 1 year
Day 0 50,000 IU 1,00,000 IU 2,00,000 IU
Day 1 50,000 IU 1,00,000 IU 2,00,000 IU
Day 2 50,000 IU 1,00,000 IU 2,00,000 IU

questions.text: What is the recommended daily dose of iodine for a child?
questions.explanation: Correct option B: 90-120 μg

questions.text: Which vitamin deficiencies are associated with the presence of cardiac edema and neuropathy?
questions.explanation:
Vitamin Cardiac Oedema Neuropathy Other Features
Thiamine  Yes Yes Wet/dry beriberi
Biotin No Rare/mild Skin and CNS changes
Pyridoxine No Yes Seizures, cheilitis, glossitis
Riboflavin No No Skin, oral, and eye symptoms

Vitamin deficiency Clinical manifestations
B1 (thiamine) deficiency
  • Beriberi
    • Wet beriberi
    • Dry beriberi
  • Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome
B2 (riboflavin) deficiency Ariboflavinosis
B3 (niacin) deficiency Pellagra
B5 (pantothenic acid) deficiency
  • Paresthesia
  • Fatigue
  • Gastrointestinal disturbances
B6 (pyridoxine) deficiency
  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Glossitis
  • Microcytic anemia
  • Seizures

questions.text: A child in your unit is diagnosed with severe acute malnutrition (SAM). According to the WHO criteria, SAM is best defined by:

options.label: A
options.text: Weight for age less than -2 SD

options.label: B
options.text: Weight for height less than +2 SD

options.label: C
options.text: Weight for age less than +3 SD

options.label: D
options.text: Weight for height less than -3 SD

questions.correct_answer: D. Weight for height less than -3 SD
questions.explanation:
Correct option D: Weight for height less than -3 SD:

References:

  • ↳ When assessing and classifying malnutrition in children, the World Health Organization (WHO) uses two primary indicators: Weight for age Weight for height
  • ↳ Weight for age Weight for height
  • ↳ Weight for age
  • ↳ Weight for height
  • ↳ These indicators are expressed as standard deviation (SD) scores, also known as Z-scores, which compare a child's measurements to the reference population.
  • ↳ In the case of severe acute malnutrition (SAM), the WHO focuses on the weight for height indicator.
  • ↳ A weight for height Z-score of less than -3 SD is used to define severe acute malnutrition.
  • ↳ Incorrect options: Options A, B, and C are incorrect.
  • ↳ Incorrect options:

questions.text: What is the mid-arm circumference measurement for severe acute malnutrition?
questions.explanation: Correct option D: < 11.5

questions.text: All are signs of adequate breastfeeding in a 2-month-old infant, except?

options.label: A
options.text: Baby sleeps for 2-3 hours after feeding

questions.correct_answer: A. Baby sleeps for 2-3 hours after feeding
questions.explanation: Correct option A: Baby sleeps for 2-3 hours after feeding

questions.text: Exclusive breastfeeding should be continued for a minimum of how many months?
questions.explanation: Correct option A: 6 month

questions.text: What is the amount of milk given to a term baby in first 24 hours after delivery?
questions.explanation: Correct option C: 60ml/kg

questions.text: Which of the following vitamins is deficient in breast milk?
questions.explanation: Correct option D: Vitamin K

questions.text: A labourer’s younger child is brought to the OPD with a swollen belly and dull face. He has mostly fed rice water in his diet. On investigations, the child was found to have low serum protein, low serum protein, and low albumin. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct option A: Kwashiork

  Kwashiorkor Marasmus
Edema Present Absent
Appetite Poor Voracious
CNS involvement Apathy and lethargy Active and alert
Hepatomegaly Usually present Usually absent
Skin and hair changes More common Less common
